The verification process includes solving a Proof of Work (POW) algorithm. This algo is the central nerve of Bitcoin. The idea behind POW is easy: make it so computationally expensive just to verify a block that attackers will be hard pressed to launch attacks and mint false coins (attacks can vary in flavor and strength, but network attacks deserve their own post. In more technical jargon, the miner takes the new transactions, data from the last mined block, and essentially a random number called a nonce and runs it through the hash function SHA-256 twice. If the output, in binary notation, has a certain amount of leading zeroes (the amount of zeroes is dictated by the difficulty rating of bitcoin, adjusted every 2 weeks based on how well miners are solving the POW), then we have produced a valid block! If not, the software changes the nonce and tries again...and again...and again. It's so hard to satisfy this condition that the top mining rigs do giga- and penta- hashes/second.
